If anything, the opportunity is even broader than it was 50 years ago. People still "work" their way through school. Many people emerge from college without debt. I went to college 30 years ago and worked my way through it and, like many today, didn't finish it in 4 years. But, like many today, still made it and achieved this canard that Stiglitz ethereally flouts as "upward mobility".

If we allow the government or economists to define our outcomes we will be forever the pawns, itinerant souls looking for something that we don't have as opposed to recognizing that which we do, and doing something about it.

Equal opportunity, as I experienced it 50 years ago, no longer exists in the US and I perceive it as a lack of equal educational opportunity.  When I started college, coming from the bottom fifth, it was possible to work one's way through school with a barely above minimum wage job.  That is rarely possible these days and cuts off a pathway out of the bottom fifth as well as many more in the bottom 60% based on income.  As Brooking's research indicates, forty-two percent of children born to parents in the bottom fifth of the income distribution remain in the bottom, while 39 percent born to parents in the top fifth remain at the top. Only 34% make more income and move up at least one quintile from their parents. The other 67% stay the same or decline.  Only 6 percent of children born to parents with family income at the bottom fifth and move to the top fifth. I was able to do this with educational opportunity, but as I note above, this is rarely possible these days and  the problem is getting worse, not better.  The household income at your birth now has a greater probability of your future success than your capabilities, no different than the class society of Downton Abbey.  In fact, the upward mobility in Britain with all its history of classes is now greater than a child born in the US.  What does that say about our country's priorities?

"Walmart employs the largest number of working poor in this country. Workers don't enjoy full time employment because Walmart would have to offer them benefits."

That is why, as the Chamber of Commerce has perfectly made clear, we need to eliminate regulations forcing businesses to pay benefits at all. If this was done part-time employees would be converted to full-time by business.

Why do liberals not understand?
I'd say we're a pretty fair cross section.

Nice job on the short-lived but successful Queen of the West.  Naval warfare on the western rivers played out in the very backyards of southern landowners. It was was exciting, unpredictable, and played a larger role in defeating the Confederacy than commonly understood.  Ships and crews had to dodge artillery batteries and snipers from shore, fire rafts, sand bars, and other obstructions and complications not faced by their deep water colleagues.  The war could not be won without control of those rivers.

Raising the minimum wage would make it possible for a few more people to support themselves rather than having to depend on government resources to help feed themselves and their families. It would go a small way to at least slow down the increasing inequality that is literally and figuratively impoverishing many more lives than just those who have to work for the minimum wage. It's also a small message to the most rapacious and exploitive of employers like Walmart that treating so many employees almost like dirt while the owners have become fabulously wealthy that even lowly paid workers have a few rights.

(too soon)

RiA, have you looked in San Francisco?

The Republican propensity to protect the income sources (industry, investment, low taxation) of the wealthiest has compromised middle class growth and even stability. The current attitude toward the lower economic classes is hostile. These attitudes will not likely change. Therefore it is imperative government act. We cannot make people want to do what is moral and supportive of the whole community, but we can pass legislation that forces moral economic behavior. In other words it is time to require employers to pay a higher minimum wage. We all benefit from more money being circulated.

I have a signed copy of Phillip Lopate's book - Personal - on my shelf from an A.P. English rating in the NASCAR city of Daytona. I want to assure Professor Lopate that there will always be a witer that will raise a "doubt".

I think the few, but significant, pieces of exhaustion with Downton Abbey is a brief reminder.

All best to Phillip Lopate and all those essayists that write for such publications as The New York Times Op Ed pages, Harper's, The New Republic, Counterpunch, The Weekly Standard, The New Yorker, Granta, The Amercian Scholar and on, and on.

Jack

As this writer points out, I often sense that the danger for any intellectual or writer is to fall into one's own way of thinking, which can be a trap.  A writer should constantly practice self-doubt, so their consciousness is in a state of ongoing development.
A wonderful essay from the prototypical thinker-against-himself.

Doubt isn't the problem, per se. Meaning and human dignity is only possible because of innate uncertainty.

The drama is the absurd notion that we are compelled to search for answers that don't exist. Man is always at war with himself, always wrong or at fault, like you point out. As the Iranian-German theologian Navid Kermani put it in "The Terror of God", the truly "disturbing aspect of death is not that we cannot know what it brings, but rather that it forces us to want to know it."

Perhaps the ultimate heresy, the one that finally "solves" contrarian doubt, is an articulation of why radical scepticism is our lot. Doubt wouldn't be so troubling if we knew why it is we must endure it.

What teachers told Lily to take position on an issue is part of a larger malaise affecting our society. I have seen politicians who take a middle position are often ridiculed and frowned upon. "You are either with us or you you are with our opposition" rings familiar bell! As someone rightly said " foolish consistency is hobgoblin of little mind."

On a serious note, essay writing is a disappearing art. I have often found management graduates are unable to express them clearly in writing, though they are genius when it comes to numbers! I feel essay writing should be made compulsory in schools. It will not only encourage students in developing a love for reading, but will also help them express their views cogently.

"The problem is that, more often than not, the applicant is expected to put forward a confident presentation of self that is more like an advertisement, a smooth civic-minded con job, circumventing the essay’s gift for candid, robust self-doubt."

I have a craft essay forthcoming in the March Issue of BREVITY: "The Admissions Essay versus The Permission Essay," which speaks to the challenge in teaching introductory nonfiction students how to write true essays because of their background in writing these types of application essays.
I doubt that.

The author manages to misconstrue Freud, Montaigne and Adorno sequentially in three paragraphs; this tells me all I need to know about his conception of the essay and its function.
,
Paul Werner
Editor, WOID
I dare you to write anything and as it progresses, to not feel just a twinge of doubt in the process.

I wonder what doubts Mr. Lopate has about his seeming assertion that doubt is the essayist's stock-in-trade.

Must every good essay come from a place of deep uncertainty? Does putting forth a confident argument undermine critical thinking? What art can come from a place of conviction?

While many essays work by "tracking consciousness" and laying bare their "candid, robust self-doubt," there seems a wide and thrilling set of essayistic possibilities lost in this characterization.

The beauty of it would be that whilst your essay may might leave you still stumbling in darkness chasing your doubts, its light might for a moment chase mine away.

I had never thought of melancholy as an idea but, rather, as a state of mind. Soon melancholy will be a Movement, the word itself will become a verb (in what construction I shudder to imagine). Such is the influence of the essayist!

I would say to Mr. Lopate that he must be cautious, as was, certainly, Montaigne, cautious to avoid rationalization: in this sense: “the ascription of one's acts, opinions, etc. to causes that seem reasonable but actually are unrelated to the true, possibly unconscious causes.”(Multiple dictionaries.)

But in that grander sense ("To make compliant to reason"), do continue, to all our benefit, to rationalize, Mr. Lopate.

I teach essay writing and find that students are uncomfortable with accepting doubt as part of the writing process.  They seem to want to know the black and white of things.  Ambiguity is a challenging state.

As F. Scott Fitzgerald observed: "The test of a first-rate intelligence is the ability to hold two opposing ideas in mind at the same time and still retain the ability to function." Or perhaps he was wrong.
The cryptic puzzles are my favorite, even when I have to struggle to get the clue even after I've figured out the answer.

I'll admit that I have no data, but I suspect that raising the minimum wage has little effect on employment for two reasons. First, most minimum wage workers produce far more than they are paid: a fast food worker generates more revenue for McDonald's than he or she costs. Second, the kind of work that minimum wage workers do is not easily outsourced. French fries can't be served via the internet. Lawns can't be mowed by robots. Office and hotel cleaning can't be shipped to Mexico. Well, companies can bring workers in from Mexico illegally and pay them minimum wage or less, but that's part of the reason that the wages paid for low-skill jobs are so low to begin with. Companies that claim that they can't find US workers to pick vegetables and process chicken are really just stating that the wages they offer are too low.
